content.text: How many chirality centers does the following molecule have? <image 1>

The molecule shown in the image has three chirality centers. Chirality centers, also known as stereocenters or chiral centers, are atoms (usually carbon) that are bonded to four different groups. In this molecule, the chirality centers are the carbon atoms marked with dashed and solid wedges, indicating the presence of tetrahedral geometry around these atoms.

1. The carbon atom bonded to the hydroxyl group (OH) on the left side.
2. The carbon atom bonded to the hydroxyl group (OH) on the right side.
3. The carbon atom bonded to the nitrogen (N) atom.

These three carbon atoms each have four different substituents attached to them, making them chirality centers.
